trial_identification.studytitle: Exercise and airway clearance practices of adults with cystic fibrosis: current Australian practice.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Exercise and airway clearance practices of adults with cystic fibrosis: current Australian practice.

interventions.interventions: Participants will self-complete a purpose-specific questionnaire that assesses their current practices in relation to exercise and airway clearance techniques over the previous three months. The questionnaire also investigates the participants' beliefs about exercise as a form of airway secretion clearance. The questionnaire collects various demographic data. Participants will only complete the questionnaire once, either during an outpatient appointment or during an inpatient admission.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Percentage of participants utilising each type of airway clearance technique as assessed by the study-specific questionnaire.
Percentage of patients using each form of exercise as assessed by the study-specific questionnaire.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Percentage reporting that exercise is a substitute or alternative to traditional airway clearance techniques as assessed by the study-specific questionnaire.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of CF Attending a participating adult CF service/site
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Unable to provide informed consent (e.g. critically unwell, terminal end of life care) Unwilling to participate Inability to understand written English Post lung transplantation Participation in an exercise or ACT interventional study in the last three months.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Demographic characteristics and airway clearance/exercise practices will be reported using descriptive statistics. Comparisons between those using exercise as a form of airway clearance, exercise to improve the effectiveness of their traditional airway clearance techniques and those who do not use exercise as a form or airway clearance will be assessed for normality and analysed using the corresponding tests. As this is a cross-sectional study to determine current clinical practice, there are no suitable data to determine a minimum sample size. Recruitment will occur at each site for 3 months or until 100% of patients at the clinic have participated, whichever occurs first. In 2013, there were 1613 adults listed on the Australian Cystic Fibrosis Data Registry. It is hoped that between 600-800 individuals Australia-wide will be recruited.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to determine the current practices of adults with cystic fibrosis in relation to exercise and airway clearance techniques in Australia. It will also examine the beliefs of these individuals regarding the use of exercise as a form of airway clearance. Potential demographic and disease-related variables will be examined to determine if they are related to the participants current practices and beliefs regarding exercise and airway clearance techniques.
